subject: Communication
title: Monroe's Motivated Sequence
description: A fast breakdown of Monroe's Motivated Sequence for builders.

hook.text: In the 1930s, a Purdue professor cracked the code for speeches that make people actually do something.

buildup.text: Alan Monroe's sequence has five steps: attention, need, satisfaction, visualization, action.

discovery.text: First grab attention, then show a problem, offer a solution, paint the future, and ask them to act.

twist.text: Most speeches skip the visualization step â€” showing what life looks like after the change.

climax.text: Every successful infomercial, charity pitch, and campaign speech follows this exact pattern.

punchline.text: Action speeches need a blueprint. Monroe drew it.

quiz.question: How many steps are in Monroe's Motivated Sequence?
